maml:description.maml:para: Add a reading to the database.
Adds a reading to the database into the specified data source.
The database to which the reading will be added.
The data source to which the reading will be added.
The value(s) of the new reading. Each value must have a corresponding timestamp in the same position in the corresponding TimeStamp array.

The timestamp(s) of the new reading. The timestamp can be 'Now' to represent the time when the reading is inserted into the database. There must be one timestamp for each value being added to the database.
The database to which the reading will be added.
The data source to which the reading will be added.
The value(s) of the new reading. Each value must have a corresponding timestamp in the same position in the corresponding TimeStamp array.

The timestamp(s) of the new reading. The timestamp can be 'Now' to represent the time when the reading is inserted into the database. There must be one timestamp for each value being added to the database.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a reading with a value of 17.0 with a timestamp of 10 July 2008 at 5:46PM into the Temperature data source.

maml:description.maml:para: Delete an existing database file.
Delete an existing database file whilst respecting the database locking mechanism.
The database to delete. Can be either a relative or full path to the TimeTag database file.
The database to delete. Can be either a relative or full path to the TimeTag database file.
Export the contents of a database.
Export the contents of a database into an XML based export file.
The database to export. Can be either a relative or full path to the TimeTag database file.
The file to export the database to.
Force an overwrite of the export file if it already exists.
The database to export. Can be either a relative or full path to the TimeTag database file.
The file to export the database to.
Force an overwrite of the export file if it already exists.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Export the contents of PowerShellTest.ptd into test.xml.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the archive object from the database file.
Reads the archive object from the database file and returns it on the object pipeline.
The database file to read.
The data source name.
The archive name to fetch.
The database file to read.
The data source name.
The archive name to fetch.
The requested archive object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the archive object specified on the command line and returns it on the pipeline.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the database object from the database file.
Reads the database object from the database file and returns it on the object pipeline.
The database file to read.
The database file to read.
The database object stored inside the database file.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the database object in PowerShellTest.ptd and returns it on the pipeline.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the data points from the database with an optional date range.
Retrieves an array of data points from the database with an optional date range.
The path to the database file to read.
The data source from which the data points will be read.
The archive from which the data points will be read.
Retrieve data points starting from this start timestamp.
Retrieve data points up to this end timestamp.
The path to the database file to read.
The data source from which the data points will be read.
The archive from which the data points will be read.
Retrieve data points starting from this start timestamp.
Retrieve data points up to this end timestamp.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Fetch all of the data points ie without a time based filter, from the All archive in the Temperature data source.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the data source object from the database file.
Reads the data source object from the database file and returns it on the object pipeline.
The path to the database file to read.
The data source name.
The path to the database file to read.
The data source name.
The requested data source.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the Temperature data source from the PowerShellTest.ptd database and returns it on the pipeline.

maml:description.maml:para: The database from which the database stats will be extracted.
The database from which the database stats will be extracted.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets the usage statistics from the specified database.

maml:description.maml:para: Import the contents of a previously exported database.
Import the contents of a previously exported database into either an existing database or a new database. If an existing database is used it will overwrite the existing contents of the file.
The database to be created and then be the subject of the import. Can be either a relative or full path to a TimeTag database file.
The file to import the database from.
Force an overwrite of the database if it already exists.
The database to be created and then be the subject of the import. Can be either a relative or full path to a TimeTag database file.
The file to import the database from.
Force an overwrite of the database if it already exists.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Import the contents of test.xml into PowerShellTest.ptd. If PowerShellTest.ptd already exists it will be overwritten.

maml:description.maml:para: The database from which the database chart data will be extracted.
The data source name.
The archive name.
The chart title.
The chart style. Can be one of: LINEMARKED, BAR or LINE.
Folder where the image file will be created.
Image file type. Can be: PNG, BMP, EXIF, GIF, JPEG, TIFF, or WMF.
The size of the image.
The Y axis label.
The X axis label.
The database from which the database chart data will be extracted.
The data source name.
The archive name.
The chart title.
The chart style. Can be one of: LINEMARKED, BAR or LINE.
Folder where the image file will be created.
Image file type. Can be: PNG, BMP, EXIF, GIF, JPEG, TIFF, or WMF.
The size of the image.
The Y axis label.
The X axis label.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1 --------------
command:example.dev:code: New-TTChart -Database PowerShellTest.ptd -DataSource Temperature -Archive All -Title ""A unit test"" -YAxisLabel ""Temperature (Centigrade)"" -XAxisLabel Time

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a chart image file from all of the data in the All archive in the Temperature data source.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new TimeTag database.
Create a new TimeTag database specifying the data source and archives that will make up the database.
Specifies the filename for the new TimeTag database.
The start time of the TimeTag database. Specify 'Now' or 'N' to use the current timestamp (DateTime.Now.)

The data sources to add to the TimeTag database. At least one data source must be specified. Each data source must be formatted in the following way:
NAME:TYPE:INTERVAL_IN_SECONDS:MIN:MAX
NAME - the name to give the data source. TYPE - the type of data source to create. Can be one of GAUGE, COUNTER, ABSOLUTE or DERIVE. INTERVAL - the expected polling interval (in seconds.) MIN - the minimum value that is valid. MAX - the maximum value that is valid.

The archive(s) to add to each data source in the TimeTag database. At least one archive must be specified. Each archive must be formatted in the following way:
NAME:TYPE:XFACTOR:READINGS_PER_DATAPOINT:NUMBER_OF_DATAPOINTS
NAME - the name of the archive. TYPE - the type of archive to create. Available types are: AVERAGE, MIN, MAX or LAST XFACTOR - the percentage of values in a given time slot that must be present in order for the value to be persisted into the database READINGS_PER_DATAPOINT - the total number of readings to collect per data point. NUMBER_OF_DATAPOINTS - the maximum number of DataPoints in the Archive. When the maximum number of data points have been stored, new data points with wrap around overwriting the oldest value.
Overwrite an existing database file if one already exists.
The title for the TimeTag database.
Specifies the filename for the new TimeTag database.
The start time of the TimeTag database. Specify 'Now' or 'N' to use the current timestamp (DateTime.Now.)

The data sources to add to the TimeTag database. At least one data source must be specified. Each data source must be formatted in the following way:
NAME:TYPE:INTERVAL_IN_SECONDS:MIN:MAX
NAME - the name to give the data source. TYPE - the type of data source to create. Can be one of GAUGE, COUNTER, ABSOLUTE or DERIVE. INTERVAL - the expected polling interval (in seconds.) MIN - the minimum value that is valid. MAX - the maximum value that is valid.

The archive(s) to add to each data source in the TimeTag database. At least one archive must be specified. Each archive must be formatted in the following way:
NAME:TYPE:XFACTOR:READINGS_PER_DATAPOINT:NUMBER_OF_DATAPOINTS
NAME - the name of the archive. TYPE - the type of archive to create. Available types are: AVERAGE, MIN, MAX or LAST XFACTOR - the percentage of values in a given time slot that must be present in order for the value to be persisted into the database READINGS_PER_DATAPOINT - the total number of readings to collect per data point. NUMBER_OF_DATAPOINTS - the maximum number of DataPoints in the Archive. When the maximum number of data points have been stored, new data points with wrap around overwriting the oldest value.
Overwrite an existing database file if one already exists.
The title for the TimeTag database.
A time series database object

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will create a new TimeTag database 'c:\example.ptd'. The database will contain a data source called 'Temperature'. Each data source will contain an archive called 'All'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 2: Creating a database with multiple data sources --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will create a new TimeTag TimeSeries Database file 'c:\example.ptd'. The database will contain two data sources called 'Temperature' and 'Relative Humidity'. Each data source will contain an archive called 'All'.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 3: Creating a database with multiple data sources and multiple archives --------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command will create a new TimeTag database file 'c:\example.ptd'. The database will contain two data sources called 'Temperature' and 'Relative Humidity'. Each data source will contain two archives called 'All' and 'Avg'.
